header.title: Research Note: The Pro Attitude and the 'Sheep-Goat' Effect in the I Ching Database

central_thesis: The 'pro attitude' (participant's conscious or unconscious attitude towards a favorable outcome) and 'psi belief' (sheep-goat effect) are crucial 'necessary conditions' for achieving psychopractic effects in I Ching experimentation, with optimal psi performance correlating with moderate interest/trust rather than extreme scores.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to Psychopraxia and I Ching Effect
structure_content.summary: Reviews previous studies by Storm and Thalbourne, establishing psychopraxia as a unitary theory of ESP and PK, and framing the I Ching effect (hexagram-hitting) as a psychopractic phenomenon manifesting exosomatically.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Second Principle: The Pro Attitude
structure_content.summary: Introduces the 'pro attitude' as a necessary condition for psychopractic effects, defined as a favorable conscious or unconscious attitude. Initial experimental attempts to measure this attitude (1-7 scale of interest) did not find a significant relationship with the I Ching effect.

structure_content.chapter_title: Critique and Re-evaluation of Pro Attitude Measurement
structure_content.summary: Identifies problems with previous investigations, citing Heath's research which suggests that extreme 'investment' or 'trust in the process' creates adverse conditions for psi, implying a non-linear relationship. Re-analysis of Storm's (2002a) data, by trimming extreme scores (1, 2, 6, 7), revealed a significant negative correlation between pro attitude (mid-range scores 3, 4, 5) and hexagram-hitting, supporting the idea that moderate interest/trust is optimal.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Third Principle: Necessary Conditions and the Sheep-Goat Effect
structure_content.summary: Discusses the psychopractic theory's third principle: the necessity of an ensemble of 'necessary conditions' to achieve a paranormal effect. Introduces the 'sheep-goat effect' (psi belief) as another identified necessary condition. Data combining Storm's (2002a) sample with another pooled sample (N=243) showed 'believers' (sheep) had significantly greater hexagram hits than chance, while 'skeptics' (goats) scored at chance.

Concludes that extreme scores on motivational and emotional variables should be treated with caution in psi research. Recommends experimenters use dual-testing procedures to identify and accumulate necessary conditions, focusing on sub-samples that elicit paranormal effects, as the psychopractic approach predicts stronger effects as more conditions are met.

key_concepts.definition: A theory proposing that ESP and PK are not fundamentally different, but unitary phenomena, with normal and paranormal effects being phenomenologically similar. The 'self' is considered its first principle, and effects can manifest exosomatically.
A specific psychopractic effect observed in parapsychological experimentation, characterized by 'hexagram-hitting' in I Ching divination tasks.

A conscious or unconscious attitude towards a favorable outcome of an action, considered a necessary condition for a psychopractic effect. Research suggests an optimal, moderate level of 'pro attitude' (caring with trust) is more conducive to psi than extreme interest.
A specific condition that must be present for a psychopractic effect to occur. An 'ensemble' of these conditions, when complete, forms the 'sufficient condition' for the effect.

A consistent finding in parapsychological research where believers in psi ('sheep') tend to score significantly higher on psi tests, and disbelievers/skeptics ('goats') tend to score at chance or below. Psi belief is considered a necessary condition for psychopractic effects.
A description of how a psychopractic effect of the self manifests 'outside the mind-body complex.'

practical_system.description: The paper outlines a research methodology for identifying 'necessary conditions' for psychopractic effects through I Ching hexagram-hitting experiments. It advocates for careful measurement and analysis of participant variables like 'pro attitude' (interest/desire for a favorable outcome) and 'psi belief' (sheep-goat distinction). The core practical implication for a practitioner is that for successful 'hexagram-hitting' (or by extension, other psi/magical effects), one should cultivate a moderate, balanced level of intention/desire ('caring with trust') rather than excessive or insufficient 'pro attitude.' Belief in psi is also posited as a fundamental necessary condition.

relevant_quotes.text: The I Ching system of divination has featured in parapsychological experimentation in two studies by Storm and Thalbourne (1998-1999; 2001a,b), and two studies by Storm (2002a,b; 2003).
The I Ching effect (i.e., hexagram-hitting-for details, see above, p. 141) was explained as a psychopractic effect of the self, manifesting exosomatically (i.e., outside the mind-body complex).

A second principle of the theory of psychopraxia is that a psychopractic effect cannot be achieved unless a participant holds a so-called pro attitude, which is a conscious or unconscious attitude towards a favourable outcome of an action.
Heath found that the 'optimal situation seemed to be one of caring about what happened combined with trust that things would work out as they should'
The well-documented sheep-goat effectÂ² has proved to be a consistent finding throughout parapsychological research, and measures of psi belief have proved reliable in predicting psi scores.

The two questions are 'Do you think it is possible for at least some people to exhibit paranormal effects in this experiment . . .' and 'Do you believe in your own abilities to exhibit paranormal effects in this experiment...'

critical_analysis.relevance: This research is highly relevant to understanding the subtle interplay of subjective states with purported paranormal phenomena, particularly within divination systems like the I Ching. For occultists, it offers a quasi-scientific framework for examining how magical intention (the 'pro attitude') and belief ('sheep-goat effect') might not operate as simple linear amplifiers but rather require a nuanced, perhaps balanced, state for optimal efficacy. The finding that extreme desire can be counterproductive aligns with esoteric teachings emphasizing detachment or 'will without wanting.' It provides a rare attempt to scientifically study the 'operative' side of a historically esoteric tool.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers and practitioners in parapsychology, experimental psychologists studying anomalous cognition, and serious students of Western Esotericism and Occultism who are interested in the scientific investigation of consciousness, intention, and belief in magical or divinatory outcomes.
